descriptionMarkdown:
*Everything* connected to a single circuit network. Green, red, pick your poison.

1) Constant Combinator outputs A = 1
2) Gates sense player, output G
3) Decider detects G > 0, outputs B = 1
4) Arithmetic Combinator takes A * B and outputs as A >>> This results in counting up 1 every tick, resets if gates cease detecting player
5) Signal turns red @ A > 60 {roughly 1 second - this is the default in the BP}
6) Player gates open @ A > 300 {roughly 5 seconds - this is the default in the BP} and train gates close

If your trains have a LONG distance between rail signals, your train may 'claim' passing through this and then take like 9 seconds to arrive... This will result in player dying. First, you should *probably* have your rail signals more frequently, but to resolve just increase the "A" value required before the gates open.

This circuit network is train-blind, but [again unless your train signals are really far apart] should be 100% safe. If it's not, increase A to preference, and become 100% safe.


\>\>Why did you make it wait a second before turning the signal red for trains?

Because gates can detect the player approaching from like 16 tiles away even if you just happen to move vaguely in their direction while doing other things. Rather than flicker the train signal off every time and potentially cause train slowdown, I would prefer the circuit be pretty sure the player is actually going towards it/wanting to pass through.  Adjust to your preference.

\>\> Why are there gates in the middle that are always open?

If the player is more than 3 tiles away from a gate and not moving towards it, the gate stops sensing the player. If the player *happened* to stop EXACTLY in the middle of the intersection it's possible for neither exterior gate to sense the player, and then since the intersection 'gives up' player access instantly once no longer sensing player, this would be bad. So I added middle gates (always open) to the circuit to add sensors in the middle. If you have a SUPER BIG crossing, put middle gates every 4-5 tiles, or turn the crossing into two separate crossings, so that you can cross one train track at a time.
title: Super Simplified Safe Train Crossing (Mark II)
